ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to design effective puzzles
I learned how to make my own puzzles and how to truly think outside of the box.
learned how the tactics to approach different puzzles
I got much better at solving puzzles and also learned what makes a puzzle satisfying.

SOOOOO MUCH!! Best course ever in learning about logic, direct reasoning and most importantly the foundation of what makes a puzzle. Applied insights to every task that you do and every difficulty and how it can act as a puzzles and what you can do to reverse engineer it or design it yourself.

I was able to do a greater deep dive into Hofstadter's Gdel, Escher, Bach, an Eternal Golden Braid that will be so helpful for the Cogntive Science degree I want to pursue. I was also able to understand more about the creation and evaluation of philosophical questions and puzzles that are key to mastering tests like the LSAT.
I was exposed to many, many new cool and interesting types of puzzles!
I gained an appreciation for the artistic design of puzzles, as well as a greater understanding of paradoxes in formal reasoning such as Gdel's incompleteness theorem.
Better at solving puzzles as more curious about contradictions

Primarily we were taught about puzzles and their creation, as well as varying philosophical approaches to puzzles. My most significant takeaway from PHIL 045 is that there is no limit to the usefulness of critical thinking in daily life.
I really enjoyed taking this class! As you might expect, I came away with a bit more skill on how to solve certain puzzles and knew a lot more about the different styles of puzzles.
All about different types of puzzles, ways to approach solving puzzles, and how to design them ourselves

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very solid course too bad its not being taught again
It was so good! We were taught in a detailed way and the work was very fun and manageable.
Strengths - really fun and informal. There was a great camaraderie between the professor and the students.
Perfect course.
This course helps students to break down key puzzles and expand their brains when it comes to looking at more and less modern puzzles.
We got to challenge ourselves by solving some tricky puzzles of all kinds with very little actual work!
No logic and philosophy, just random puzzles

The strengths of this course were that most of the learning had its basis in the discussion and analysis of puzzles. We would start every class with a new type or several new types of puzzles, talk about their rules, attempt one puzzle together, discuss it, try another puzzle of the same type on our own, then discuss the solution. The most incredible aspect of this class was the breadth of knowledge made available to us about puzzles. Before taking PHIL 045, I had prior exposure to about 15% of the puzzles we learned about in class. There were not many visible weaknesses of the course, but one that stood out to me was that there was not as much opportunity for exploring these puzzles on our own as I had hoped for. Whether it was trying to create our own versions of puzzles we had learned about in class or developing puzzles of our own inspiration, I wish there had been more opportunities for solving puzzles outside of class.
This course was super super fun and entertaining. The coursework was low and any student could honestly get by with just staying engaged during class time. No weaknesses!

Strengths: incredibly engagingthis is an absolutely unique course that really digs into a specific (and very interesting) subject: puzzles. Class atmosphere was also great and everyone felt bonded. The escape rooms we got to do were definitely also a plus!
Weakness: none that I could really think of, but if youre looking for a more traditional class this might not be for you

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: YES. Burton is extraordinary, the course is extraordinary, and the material is extraordinary. What else could you ask for in a class?
Yes, such a great course and engaging material
YES! Such a fun and cool class!! You become a puzzle master!
yes
If you are looking for a creative outlet that is not much work

Heres a cryptic crossword:
Go from the end of Uruguay to the beginning of Spain in native language (3).
.
Answer below:
Yes

1000%. Chillest class ever. I had so much fun. We showed up to class and solved fun puzzles together, and then came up with a few of our own. Thats it. I dont really understand how this counted as a class lmao but hey Ill take it!
Yes! It is an incredible course with an incredible professor. The homework "puzzle compositions" were very fun to come up with, and the readings from GEB were always interesting.
Yes if youre looking for a gut humanities where everyday you literally just show up and do a different kind of puzzle or go on a class field trips to an escape room

I would absolutely recommend this class to another student. The course was taught with enthusiasm and open dialogue, so we all felt comfortable asking questions and making contributions. If one is interested in logical and philosophical puzzles, this class will meet and exceed all expectations.
Yes! A super fun class, very easy, easy to meet other first-years in.
100%!! Best course I have taken at Yale. Truly unfortunate that no other class will get to experience it though.
